description: Celebration of the birth of Lord Krishna, observed on the eighth day of the dark fortnight in the month of Bhadrapada.
Monthly fasting day observed on the eleventh day of both the waxing and waning phases of the moon, dedicated to Lord Vishnu, including Krishna.
Celebrated to honor the lifting of the Govardhan Hill by Lord Krishna to protect his devotees from Indra's wrath.
A significant festival in the month of Kartik, celebrated with devotional activities and often associated with Krishna's various pastimes.
Festival of colors celebrating the victory of good over evil, including Krishna's playful activities with his devotees.
Celebration of the birth of Radha, the divine consort of Krishna, observed on the eighth day of the dark fortnight in the month of Bhadrapada.
Festival commemorating the victory of Lord Rama (an incarnation of Vishnu) over the demon king Ravana, and also associated with Krishna's leelas.
Celebration of the day when the Bhagavad Gita was spoken by Lord Krishna to Arjuna on the battlefield of Kurukshetra.
Festival of lights celebrating the victory of light over darkness and good over evil, including Krishna's role in various divine pastimes.
Hindu festival dedicated to the Sun God, Surya, celebrated with devotion and offerings to Lord Krishna.
Festival observed by women for the well-being of their children and family, with devotional activities dedicated to Krishna.
Festival marking the transition of the sun into the zodiac sign of Capricorn, celebrated with devotion and reverence towards Krishna.
Nine-night festival dedicated to the worship of the Hindu goddess Durga, including fasting and devotional practices that also honor Krishna.
Month dedicated to Lord Shiva, but also celebrated with devotion to Krishna, particularly on Mondays.
Festival celebrating the birth of Lord Ganesha, with festivities and prayers that also include reverence to Krishna.
Festival marking the arrival of spring and dedicated to Goddess Saraswati, with celebrations that include devotional activities for Krishna.
Festival celebrating the annual procession of Lord Jagannathâ€™s chariot, associated with Krishna's divine play in the city of Puri.
A fasting day observed by women for the welfare and longevity of their children, including devotion to Krishna.
Festival dedicated to Goddess Gauri, observed on the third day of the bright fortnight of Bhadrapada month, with offerings and prayers to Krishna.
Ceremonial marriage of the Tulsi plant with Lord Vishnu, celebrated with devotion and prayers to Krishna.
Great night dedicated to Lord Shiva, observed with fasting and night-long vigils, including devotion to Krishna as part of the broader worship.
Celebration of the birth of Lord Hanuman, observed with prayers and recitations of the Hanuman Chalisa, with reverence to Krishna.
Celebration of the birth of Lord Rama, an incarnation of Vishnu, which includes devotional activities and reverence towards Krishna.
Day dedicated to honoring and expressing gratitude to one's spiritual teachers and guides, including the teachings of Krishna.
Harvest festival celebrated primarily in South India, including devotional activities and offerings to Krishna.
Fasting day observed on the fourth day of the waning moon, dedicated to Lord Ganesha, and also associated with Krishna's blessings.
Festival marking the beginning of Diwali, dedicated to the worship of Lord Dhanvantari, with prayers and offerings to Krishna.
Festival celebrating the bond between brothers and sisters, with devotional activities including prayers to Krishna.
Festival celebrating the bond between brothers and sisters, with sisters tying a protective thread on their brothers' wrists and offering prayers, including devotion to Krishna.
